Award.AwardTitle: Pitzer College Mentors Enable, Connect, Help, Advocate, Nurture, Intervene, Sustain, and Motivate (MECHANISM) for Success in the Molecular Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the Mentors Enable, Connect, Help, Advocate, Nurture, Intervene, Sustain, and Motivate (MECHANISM) project a team of faculty and administrators at Pitzer College is increasing the number of academically talented students with demonstrated financial need who earn baccalaureate degrees in chemistry, biochemistry, or molecular biology. The project is recruiting sixteen first-year students with the goal of retaining them to graduation in the selected STEM fields through a comprehensive program of student development that emphasizes the value of utilizing academic resources. In providing increased access to these majors, the project is contributing to the enlargement of the STEM workforce that can help meet regional and national needs. In addition, to broaden participation, students from groups that are under-represented in the sciences - African American, Latino(a) American, Asian American/Pacific Islander, and Native American (ALANA) - are actively being recruited.

Technical features of the project implementation involve students in an array of opportunities including (a) learning from peer mentors (tutoring and supplemental instruction), (b) improving written communication skills (Writing Center), (c) experiencing other cultures (Study Abroad), (d) creating peer networks and practicing high-level reasoning skills (Howard Hughes Medical Institute Summer Immersion Program), (d) contributing to cutting-edge research, and (e) participating in internships. Data generated through assessment and evaluation is expected to support the rationale that high retention of students in STEM fields is achievable through cultivation of "cultural capital," (e.g. dispositions, attitudes, and beliefs related to students' academic success throughout their academic careers). Project evaluation focuses on student academic engagement and use of support services, student content knowledge, and faculty feedback. Moreover, the project expects to track its students after graduation and interview them about the project's ongoing impact. Dissemination of the project results is expected to provide a model for how helping STEM students develop cultural capital can be used as a means of retaining them through graduation. The project team plans to present its work through Teaching and Learning Centers in the Claremont Colleges Consortium as well as through national meetings of the American Chemical Society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pitzer College was awarded an S-STEM grant (DUE 1356684, April 2014-March 2020) entitled Mentors Enable, Connect, Help, Advocate, Nurture, Intervene, Sustain, and Motivate (MECHANISM) for SUCCESS in the Molecular Sciences. The major goals of the project were to provide scholarships to two cohorts of students (16 students total) who demonstrated financial need, academic ability, and who majored in a Science, Technology, Engineering, or Math (STEM) field. The scholarships were meant to eliminate the need for work-study and allow students to graduate with little to no loan debt for all four years of a student?s undergraduate career. The scholarships ranged from $7,000-$10,000 each year per Scholar. In addition to the funding, scholarship recipients were provided with academic and co-curricular support through significant interventions to ensure optimal use of educational resources and learning experiences. These interventions are known as Pivotal Moments, and are achieved through high impact practices and dedicated mentoring by faculty and staff at Pitzer College and the Keck Science Department.

A variety of interventions were provided for students during their time as MECHANISM Scholars to help them persist in their STEM major:

  • All incoming first year MECHANISM Scholars were invited to participate in the Keck Science Department summer bridge program for First-Generation, low income, and/or students traditionally underrepresented in the sciences.
  • Faculty who taught courses that were typically challenging for all students (e.g. Organic Chemistry and Introductory Physics) wrote iTunes University Courses for the students to practice the key skills that students need to be successful at the start of the courses. The Scholars completed these prep courses over the summer.
  • Faculty grant Principal Investigators (PIs) were added as an official secondary academic advisors to all of the scholarship recipients, in addition to their major advisor, to provide academic advice and support.
  • The PIs organized roundtable lunch sessions monthly during each semester to introduce scholars to various resources on campus, faculty members, and opportunities for their academic growth. This included preparation for senior thesis (meeting with Director of the Writing Center and Science Librarians); thinking about preparation for applying for summer research internships, graduate school or jobs (faculty in Keck Science and Director of Career Services); etc.
  • The PIs Encouraged participation in and helped identify appropriate summer research programs. Scholars did research at institutions such as Columbia University, the Scripps Oceanographic Institute, Stanford University, Northwestern University, etc.

Assessment of the MECHANISM program was critical to learn which interventions were helpful to them and how they could benefit from additional support. Overall, the findings indicate that the MECHANISM program served as an academic, personal, and professional resource for students to help them remain STEM majors, apply to research opportunities, seek internships, and make plans for post-graduation.  The PIs responded to the needs of the Scholars as identified in the assessment reports. For example, some Scholars said that they did not feel prepared for college because they attended under-resourced high schools. The PIs advocated for additional resources and helped facilitate one-on-one tutoring for students who were struggling academically in their science classes.

The MECHANISM Scholars program finishes after this academic year, when the final cohort of students graduate in May 2020. Five Scholars graduated in May 2019 and an additional ten will graduate in May 2020 (one in May 2021), all with STEM majors. The interventions and support provided to the Scholars prepared them for applying to graduate programs or to enter the scientific workforce post-graduation.

Of the first cohort of students, one student is pursuing a doctorate in Biomedical Engineering at Vanderbilt University; one is applying for doctoral programs in the History of Mathematics; two are working in industry for the year and plan to attend medical school next year; and one is doing research with a Sea Turtle non-profit organization in Panama (and just received a Fulbright Fellowship to do additional research in Panama). The second cohort of 10 students will graduate in May 2020 and the students are currently applying for graduate school programs and looking for jobs outside of academia. One student will attend a Ph.D. program in Chemical Biology at the University of Illinois. Five of the other Scholars plan to take a gap year, working as a technician in a scientific laboratory, and then apply to Ph.D. programs in STEM. One Scholar has applied for a Fulbright Scholarship to do scientific research in Uraguay, 2 scholars are looking for permanent work in the STEM workforce, and one Scholar plans to do research in a biomedical research laboratory before applying to MD/Ph.D. programs next year.

Overall, the MECHANISM program has been successful in providing the support that these high-achieving, low-income students needed to successfully complete a STEM major and enter the STEM work force or graduate programs.
